title: 103_hr4502
content: The Exchange Rate Policy Reporting Act of 1994 requires the Federal Reserve Board to present semiannual reports to Congress. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require the Chairman of the Board of Governors to present reports to Congress twice a year. The Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is required to appear before Congress twice a year along with the Secretary of the Treasury. The reports must include the impact of monetary policy on the exchange rate of the US dollar and any anticipated changes. The report required under this section must include information on currency swaps, including descriptions of currency swap agreements, changes in currency inventories, and outstanding foreign loans and lines of credit. The report must include details on foreign entities, swap agreements, currency transactions, reasons, benefits, anticipated effects of monetary policy on exchange rates, and anticipated changes in matters required to be reported. SEC. 3. REPORTS OF THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY UNDER THE OMNIBUS TRADE AND COMPETITIVENESS ACT OF 1988. Section 3005 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 (22 U.S.C. 5305) is amended to update reporting requirements regarding the exchange rate of the United States dollar. The amended Section 3005 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 requires a report on the exchange rate of the US dollar, including factors affecting it and its impact on various economic aspects. The amended Section 3005 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 requires a report on the exchange rate of the US dollar, including factors affecting it and its impact on various economic aspects. The report should also include details on external indebtedness, currency swap agreements, inventory of currencies, and foreign loans or lines of credit with foreign entities. Additionally, the report does not mandate the implementation of disclosed plans by the Secretary if deemed unnecessary. The Secretary may submit a report to Congress if policies cannot be carried out or objectives achieved due to changing conditions. Any revisions or deviations from plans must be explained in the next report. If the Secretary intervenes in currency markets, a report must be submitted to Congress within 24 hours of the intervention. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 24 hours of intervening in currency markets, detailing the reasons for the intervention and its objectives. Additionally, the report submitted in July each year should include the Secretary's plans for the exchange rate of the US dollar in the upcoming year and anticipated changes in relevant matters. The Secretary is also required to appear before Congressional committees upon invitation to discuss these issues. The Senate is required to present a report and answer questions on United States policy when the Chairman of the Federal Reserve appears before Congressional committees.
